nodes.name: adult or young person presents with suspected transient loss of consciousness

value.name: adult or young person presents with suspected transient loss of consciousness
value.description: title:adult or young person presents with suspected transient loss of consciousness

value.name: information and advice
value.description: title:information and advicehead:Information and adviceWhen communicating with the person who had TLoC, discuss the: possible causes of their TLoC benefits and risks of any test they are offered results of tests they have had reasons for any further investigations nature and extent of uncertainty in the diagnosis.subhead:Advice to give when a person presents with TLoC Driving: give advice about eligibility to drive (please refer to the DVLA for further information). Health and safety at work: advise people of the implications of their episode for health and safety at work and any action they must take to ensure the safety of themselves and other people. Please refer to Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974.NICE has written information for the public explaining the guidance on transient loss of consciousness.SourcesThe NICE guidance that was used to create this part of the interactive flowchart. CG109

nodes.name: determine appropriate management and urgency of treatment

value.name: determine appropriate management and urgency of treatment
value.description: title:determine appropriate management and urgency of treatmenthead:Determine appropriate management and urgency of treatmentUse clinical judgement to determine appropriate management and the urgency of treatment if: the person has sustained an injury the person has not made a full recovery of consciousness TLoC is secondary to a condition that requires immediate action.SourcesThe NICE guidance that was used to create this part of the interactive flowchart. CG109

nodes.name: if the cause of transient loss of consciousness remains uncertain

value.name: if the cause of transient loss of consciousness remains uncertain
value.description: title:if the cause of transient loss of consciousness remains uncertainhead:If the cause of transient loss of consciousness remains uncertainIf a person has persistent TLoC, consider psychogenic non-epileptic seizures or psychogenic pseudosyncope if, for example: the nature of the events changes over time there are multiple unexplained physical symptoms there are unusually prolonged events.The distinction between epilepsy and non-epileptic seizures is complex; therefore, refer for neurological assessment if either psychogenic non-epileptic seizures or psychogenic pseudosyncope is suspected.Advise people to try to record any future TLoC events (for example, a video recording or a detailed witness account of the event), particularly if the diagnosis is unclear or taking a history is difficult.If after further assessment the cause of TLoC remains uncertain or the person has not responded to treatment, consider other causes, including the possibility that more than 1 mechanism may co-exist (for example, ictal arrhythmias).SourcesThe NICE guidance that was used to create this part of the interactive flowchart. CG109
